title: Housing shortage forecast no fantasy
text:
Tim Johansen, the global head of capital at development financier Qualitas says the Reserve Bank's view that a housing shortage could emerge is further reason why banks should rethink how they lend.

Reserve Bank deputy governor Guy Debelle said this week that the construction downturn and the lowest housing turnover in more than 30 years was hurting employment and consumption, keeping inflation low and leading to a housing shortage in the "foreseeable future" that would push up prices.

His comments came a day after Commonwealth Bank of Australia forecast an apartment supply shortage by mid next year.

"There might be a lot of cranes on the skyline but that masks what is happening," Mr Johansen, whose business is backed by RBA board member Carol Schwartz, said.

"We think the supply has dropped off big time and it's taking a lot longer to get a new development started.

"We know the headspace of apartment buyers is mixed at the moment but there comes a tipping point where that changes very quickly."
description: Qualitas' Tim Johansen, whose business is backed by RBA board member Carol Schwartz, says the cranes on the skyline "mask what is happening".
